<plain_text><page sequence="1">One Hundred Twelfth Critical Bibliography of the History of Science and its Cultural Influences Edited by John Neu Bibliographer for the History of Science University of Wisconsin Memorial Library in cooperation with the Department of the History of Science University of Wisconsin The classification system for the annual Critical Bibliography is based on that developed by George Sarton in 1913 and revised by committee in 1953. In the first two sections will be found references to histories of science in general and to historiographical, philosophical, sociological, and humanistic aspects of science. Section C indexes general books and articles relating to specific sciences. Section D contains all references that relate to the sciences in specific historical periods. Preference is given to the latter, so that historians interested in a particular science, biology, for example, must look in both the general section on the biological sciences (24) as well as the biological section under each of the historical periods. The bibliography is compiled by the systematic search of approximately 500 journals, a check- ing of several hundred more journals as they come to the editor's attention on their way to the stacks of the University of Wiscon- sin's Memorial Library, a careful watch of book production (again mainly through the resources of the Memorial Library), and the contributions of interested scholars. Those wishing to be assured of having their publi- cations listed in the bibliography are urged to notify the editor either by off-print or cita- tion. (See the "Suggestions for Contributors" on page two.) The current publication schedule calls for the bibliography to be issued in late December as the last installment of the volume. The bibliography will, therefore, include material published up to September of the year in which it is printed. Many times older citations will be included, simply because the editor has not come across them earlier, or, more frequently, because the journals are behind publication schedule or the library, for one reason or another, has not received its copy. Anyone contributing citations to be included in the bibliography should have them to the editor by September 1. BOOK REVIEWS Citations to book reviews will be found at the end of the classified section of the bibli- ography. The bibliographical information on books reviewed is abbreviated, since complete information can be found in the classified sec- tion of the present bibliography or in previous issues. JOURNAL ABBREVIATIONS The bibliography contains citations from the following periodicals and serials, with ab- breviations according to the American Na- tional Standard for the Abbreviation of Titles of Periodicals. Those marked with an asterisk are searched regularly each year by the staff of the CB and are included in the list whether or not a reference has been made to them in the present CB. Scholars publishing articles per- tinent to the scope of this bibliography in jour- nals not marked with an asterisk are urged to notify the editor so the article can be entered in the CB. Acta Hist. ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS The editor wishes to thank Patricia Harris, graduate student in the History of Science Department, University of Wisconsin-Madi- son, for her help in the compilation of the present bibliography. Gratefully acknowl- edged, also, is the help of my colleaques in the Library, Yvonne Schofer, John Tedeschi, and Karl Zangerle, in proofreading the French, Italian and German citations. A history of western science. xi + 388 pp., bibl., index. Englewood Cliffs, N.J.: Prentice-Hall, 1987. 2 CARROLL, P. THOMAS. American science transformed. Amer. Scient., 1986, 74: 466-485. The advancement of science, and its burdens: The Jefferson Lecture and other essays. xi + 351 pp., illus., notes, index. Cambridge: Cambridge Univ. Press, 1986. Contents: Thematic presuppositions and the direction of scientific advance. Einstein's model for constructing a scientific theory. Einstein's scientific program: The formative years. Einstein's search for the Weltbild. Einstein and the shaping of our imagination. Physics in America, and Einstein's decision to immigrate. "Success sanctifies the means": Heisenberg, Oppenheimer, and the transition to modern physics. Do scientists need a philosophy? Science, technology, and the fourth discontinuity. The two maps. From the endless frontier to the ideology of limits. Methaphors in science and education. "A nation at risk" revisited. Kuhn, de son c6ot, met cette facon de comprendre des acteurs et des auteurs en relation avec la methode hermeneutique. "I have been conveying basically the same message for over 30 years, namely, the significance in human affairs of the history of technology and the value of the contextual approach in understanding technical developments...My thoughts have jelled into what have been called 'Kranzberg's Laws'. Architect. Hist., 1984, 43: 60-64. "Boullee's prediliction for monumental dimensions and his admiration for Newton's momentous definition of the mathematical basis of the form of the universe brought on a new stage in the interrelation of cosmology and architecture. Combining the new gigantic leap in scale with an architectural use of mathematically pure geometric forms of the sphere and the pyramid...Boullee 'landscaped' two centuries ago the emotional setting of Orwell's 1984. He also revealed the threat of an 'unexamined' submission of the forces of representation, and of architecture, to the inhuman dictates of a totally mathematical science." 869 VON BRAUN, WERNHER; ORDWAY, FREDERICK I. Kuttaka and qiuyishu. Indian J. Hist. Sci., 1984, 19: 397-405. The solution of the equation by-ax=c is called kuf p aka in India. Qiuyishu is a method of division in Chinese mathematics. In this article, the historical parallels between these two methods are explored. 1342 BHATNAGAR, M.S. The concept of matter and its states in Indian literature. Indian J. Hist. Sci., 1984,19:125-142. 1343 DATTA, BIBHUTIBHUSAN; SINGH, AWADESH NARAYAN. Use of calculus in Hindu mathematics. Indian J. Hist. Sci., 1984, 19: 95-104. In 1858, Pandit Bapu Deva Sastri claimed that Bhaskara II had used calculus in Siddhanta Siromani (1150). This Hindu claim to the invention of differential calculus is examined and refuted. 1344 KUIPER, F.B.J. Ancient Indian cosmogony. Sci., 1984, 19: 279-292. "The riiyantra (the Great or Supreme yantra) is the ancient geometrical portrayal and it belongs to the class of objects ( yantras) which are used for meditation in various schools of tantrism." In this article, the geometrical properties of the Sryantra seal are used to explore its origin. 1346 LAGADHA. Vedanga Jyotisa, in its Rk and Yajus recensions. With the translation and notes of T.S. The Far East: Exact Sciences 1354 MAJUMDAR, M. Risala dar Falahat. [Persian manuscript on agriculture and horticulture]. Indian J. Hist. Sci., 1984, 19: 341-360. In the collection of the Asiatic Society, Calcutta, there are several Persian manuscripts on agriculture, of which the Risala dar Faldhat is the largest and most exhaustive. The dates of transcription are generally during the 18th century, but the original text is probably a century or two older. The contents of the manuscript are summarized here. 35.1f. New York: Abaris Books, 1986. 1468 DIAMOND, NORMAN. The Coperican revolution: Social foundations of concep, tualization in science. Pp. 7-37 in Les Levidow (ed.) Science as politics. (Radical science, 20). London: Free Association Books, 1986. "This essay explores the social roots of concept-formation in science. Drawing on a case study, 16th-century astronomy, it looks also at the nature of the social transition which the conceptual shift manifests. At the end, it attempts to redress the dialectical balance by reacknowledging the reciprocal influences, not only society on concepts but consciousness on social conditions, and turning more explicitly to the political implications of that reciprocity. It does so with the intention of clarifying the possibilities of a revolutionary transformation of our society." 1469 DOBRZYCKI, JERZY. One Copernican table. Em- pirics and charlatans in early modern France: The genesis of the classification of the "other" in medical practice. J. Soc. Hist., 1986,19: 583-603. "This essay examines how university-trained physicians transformed their comeptitors into a medical 'other', that is, a group considered morally and professionally unfit to practice medicine. We will concentrate upon the writings of Breil and Courval. They were the only two French physicians to write sustained attacks against 'illicit' healers in the late 16th and early 17th centuries." 1533 MERCURIALI, GIROLAMO. Le "Giornale de'Letterati" de Rome, 1668-1681. (Accademia Toscana di Scienze e Lettere "La Colombaria", studi 69.) 403 pp., bibl., index. Firenze: Olschki, 1984. 1603 GARIN, EUGENIO. Fra '500 e '600: Scienze nuove, metodi nuovi, nuove accademie. Nuncius, 1986, 1(1): 3-23. The origins of the Accademia dei Lincei are rooted in a moment of deep theoretical tension, between methods that reflect the weight of the great Greek scientific texts which had returned into circulation andSthe fresh contributions of empirical data, particularly enriched by the new discoveries. At the same time magic-hermetic influences existed alongside positions of great rational validity. In the work of Cesi and of the first Lincei, different forces and different ways of conceiving the science of nature, from the "segreti" and the "magia" of Della Porta to the "ragione" and "esperienze" of the Galileans are interwoven. The author attemps to provide a comprehensive picture of this pattern drawing extensively on the "Carteggio Lincei". (From the English summary) 1604 GARIN, EUGENIO. During Pell's stay in the Netherlands (1643-1562), he was concerned mainly with refuting a quadrature of the circle that was published by Longomontanus in 1644. Scientific dis- coveries and the end of natural philosophy. Soc. Stud. Sci., 1986, 16: 387-420. Uses case studies of four late-18th-century instances of scientific discovery to show how "discovery was a label given to a set of events and to the work of a specific author. The label was granted retrospectively by a research community, and the process of labelling was co-extensive with the fixing of a group of practices pursued by that community." This paper is a greatly revised version of "Scoperte scientifiche alla fine del XVIII secolo", Materiali filosofici 1984, 12: 97-114. 1911 SCHOSLER, JORN. Eighteenth Century: Earth Sciences 1999 CAROZZI, MARGUERITE. From the concept of salient and reentrant angles by Louis Bourguet to Nicolas Desmarest's description of meandering rivers. Arch. Sci. (Geneva), 1986, 39: 25-51. "Between 1729 and 1803, the abstract concept of corresponding salient and reentrant angles evolved into the modern description of meandering rivers. Louis Bourguet believed that the concept of corresponding angles in mountains was the key to the theory of the earth... In 1803, Desmarest came to the conclusion that the concept of corresponding angles had been merely used by naturalists to prove or disprove a theory and that nobody had actually studied meandering rivers which in fact produce such corresponding angles." 2000 CENTENAIRE de la mort de Laperouse, 1888. Mystery of the forbidden fruit: Historical epilogue on the origin of the grapefruit, Citrus paradisi (Rutaceae). Econ. Bot., 1987, 41: 97-107. Early colonial settlers of Barbados (ca. 1700) first planted the grapefruit, but early botanists mididentified it as a variety of shaddock. James Macfadyen, the botanist who named grapefruit, was misled by these errors. The authors have been able to prove the existence of a Captain Shaddock, who is said to have brought the first seeds of the shaddock to Barbados. 2043 LACK, EVA. "Lord Kelvin's Britain refers here to the consistent vision of an industrialized empire that transformed plain William Thomson into Sir William and thence into Lord Kelvin. We shall tie together...Pierre Duhem's caricature of British theorizing, particularly Thomson's, as representative of a factory mentality, and Thomson's own perception of measurement as the root of all scientific understanding...We show how measurement expressed Thomson's most cherished ideals of progress, mixing together 'value' as the numerical value of a quantity and 'value' as economic and moral value." 2425 WRIGHT, HELEN. Although the 1821 prize competition was designed to defend Lavoisier's theory of the causes of animal heat, the chief contestants could not quantitatively confirm his theory. Used mainly in the second half of the 19th century, they were intended for optical demonstrations and the illumination of microscopes and similar apparatus, rather than for astronomical applications. 2882 MOYAL, ANN. Technikgeschichte, 1986, 53: 223-234. The procedure for the electrolysis of gold chloride was developed in 1878 by the industrial chemist Emil Wohlwill and was improved in 1903 by his son Heinrich Wohlwill. This paper discusses the practical and theoretical problems both chemists had to cope with. 2891 SICILIA, DAVID B. Steam power and the progress of industry in the late 19th century. William Draper Harkins, Andrew MacLeish Distinguished Service Professor at the University of Chicago, made a number of valuable contributions to nuclear chemistry and surface chemistry. His views were often ahead of his time and even when they were later confirmed experimentally, he was often denied real credit. Because of his efforts to obtain recognition he was called "Priority Harkins". G.B. KAUFFMAN 3075 KERKER, MILTON. The Svedberg and molecular reality: An autobiographical postscript. The discovery of pluralistic ignorance: An ironic lesson. J. Hist. Behav. Sci., 1986, 22: 333-347. "In recent years, an increasing number of social and behavioral scientists have begun to pay serious attention to pluralistic ignorance, the shared false ideas of individuals about the sentiments, thoughts, and actions of others. Most of these researchers are unaware of the original effort to investigate these patterns of cognitive error and, consequently, misunderstand, as did the original investigators, some of the implications of their own work. The discovery of this important phenomenon by Floyd H. Allport and his students, Daniel Katz and Richard L. Schanck...is discussed." 3344 OPITZ, MICHAEL J.
